column1: Ashdod (Hebrew: אַשְׁדּוֹד‎; Arabic: أشدود‎) is the sixth-largest city and the largest port in Israel accounting for 60% of the country's imported goods. Ashdod is located in the Southern District of the country
column2: on the Mediterranean coast where it is situated between Tel Aviv to the north 32 kilometres (20 miles) away
column3: and Ashkelon to the south 20 km (12 mi) away. Jerusalem is 53 km (33 mi) to the east. The city is also an important regional industrial center.

column1: Modern Ashdod covers the territory of two ancient twin towns
column2: one inland and one on the coast
column3: which were for most of their history two separate entities
column4: connected by close ties with each other. This article deals with these historic towns
column5: including other ancient nearby sites
column6: and modern Ashdod.

column1: The first documented urban settlement at Ashdod dates to the Canaanite culture of the 17th century BCE.  Ashdod is mentioned 13 times in the Bible. During its pre-1956 history the city was settled by Philistines
column2: Israelites
column3: Greek colonists coming in the wake of Alexander's conquests
column4: Romans and Byzantines
column5: Arabs
column6: Crusaders
column7: and Ottoman Turks.Modern Ashdod was established in 1956 on the sand hills near the site of the ancient town
column8: and incorporated as a city in 1968
column9: with a land-area of approximately 60 square kilometres (23 sq mi). Being a planned city
column10: expansion followed a main development plan
column11: which facilitated traffic and prevented air pollution in the residential areas
column12: despite population growth. According to the Israel Central Bureau of Statistics
column16: 242 dunams (47.242 km2; 18.240 sq mi).Ashdod today is home to the largest Moroccan Jewish community in Israel
column17: the largest Karaite Jewish community in Israel
column18: and the largest Georgian Jewish community in the world.

column1: Three stone tools dating from the Neolithic era were discovered
column2: but no other evidence of a Stone Age settlement in Ashdod was found
column3: suggesting that the tools were deposited there in a later period.

column1: The site of Ashdod in the Bronze Age was at a tell just south of the modern city. It was excavated by archaeologists in nine seasons between 1962 and 1972. The effort was led during the first few years by David Noel Freedman of the Pittsburgh Theological Seminary and Moshe Dothan. The remaining seasons were headed by Dothan for the Israel Antiquities Authority.
The earliest major habitation in Ashdod dates to the 17th century BCE. Ashdod was fortified in MBIIC with a two-entryway city gate (similar to Shechem).
Ashdod is first mentioned in written documents from Late Bronze Age Ugarit
column2: which indicate that the city was a center of export for dyed woolen purple fabric and garments. At the end of the 13th century BCE the Sea Peoples conquered and destroyed Ashdod. By the beginning of the 12th century BCE
column3: the Philistines
column4: generally thought to have been one of the Sea Peoples
column5: ruled the city. During their reign
column6: the city prospered and was a member of the Philistine Pentapolis (i.e. five cities)
column7: which included Ashkelon and Gaza on the coast and Ekron and Gath farther inland
column8: in addition to Ashdod.

column1: In 950 BCE Ashdod was destroyed during Pharaoh Siamun's conquest of the region. The city was not rebuilt until at least 815 BCE.
Asdûdu led the revolt of Philistines
column2: Judeans
column3: Edomites
column4: and Moabites against Assyria after expulsion of king Ahimiti
column5: whom Sargon had installed instead of his brother Azuri. Gath (Gimtu) belonged to the kingdom of Ashdod at that time. Assyrian king Sargon II's commander-in-chief (turtanu)
column6: whom the King James Bible calls simply "Tartan" (Isaiah 20:1)
column7: regained control of Ashdod in 712/711 BCE and forced the usurper Yamani to flee. Sargon's general destroyed the city and exiled its residents
column8: including some Israelites who were subsequently settled in Media and Elam.Mitinti was king at the time of Sargon's son Sennacherib (r. 705–681 BCE)
column9: and Akhimilki in the reign of Sennacherib's son Esarhaddon (r. 681–669 BCE).

column1: Psamtik I of Egypt (r. 664 – 610 BCE) is reported to have besieged the great city Azotus for twenty-nine years (Herodotus
column2: ii. 157); the biblical references to the remnant of Ashdod (Jeremiah 25:20; cf. Zephaniah 2:4) are interpreted as allusions to this event.

column1: The city absorbed another blow in 605 BCE
column2: when Nebuchadnezzar conquered it.In 539 BCE the city was rebuilt by the Persians. In 332 BCE it was conquered in the wars of Alexander the Great.
the Ashdodites seem to represent the whole nation of the Philistines in the sixth century BCE
column3: the speech of Ashdod (which half of the children from mixed families are described as adopting) would simply be the general Philistine dialect. Hugo Winckler explains the use of that name by the fact that Ashdod was the nearest of the Philistine cities to Jerusalem.

column3: he was on the following morning again found prostrate and broken. The people of Ashdod were smitten with boils; a plague of mice was sent over the land (1 Samuel 6:5).

column1: The village of Isdud was occupied by the Egyptian army on May 29
column3: and became the Egyptians' northernmost position during the 1948 Arab-Israeli War. While the Israelis failed to capture territory
column4: and suffered heavy casualties
column5: Egypt changed its strategy from offensive to defensive
column6: thus halting their advance northwards. Egyptian and Israeli forces clashed in the surrounding area
column7: with the Egyptians being unable to hold the Ad Halom bridge over the Lachish River. Israeli forces surrounded the town during Operation Pleshet
column8: and shelled and bombed it from the air. For three nights from 18 October the Israeli Air Force bombed Isdud and several other locations. Fearing encirclement
column10: 1948 and the majority of the residents fled. The 300 townspeople who remained were driven southwards by the Israel Defense Forces. The village was part of territory that was granted to Israel in the 1949 Armistice Agreements following the end of the war.

column1: The city's development was made possible by the large investment of industrialist Israel Rogosin who opened his main Israeli factory in the city of Ashdod on August 9
column2: 1960. Three of the high schools he funded were also built in Ashdod. The Main boulevard in Ashdod is named in his honour as a founder of the city.

column2: Ashdod was a town of 4
column3: 600. The Magistrates' Court in the city was inaugurated in 1963. The building of the port of Ashdod began in April 1961. The port was inaugurated in November 1963
column4: and was first utilized in November 1965

column1: Large-scale growth of the city began in 1991

column3: 000 new inhabitants
column4: a 150% growth. Five more quarters of the city were completed
column5: and a business district was built. In the 2000s

column1: Ashdod was one of six cities that won the 2012 Education Prize awarded by the Israel Ministry of Education.
The modern city of Ashdod city was built outside the historic settlement site
column2: on virgin sands. The development followed a main development plan. The planners divided the city into seventeen neighborhoods of ten to fifteen thousand people. Wide avenues between the neighborhoods make traffic flow relatively freely inside the city. Each neighborhood has access to its own commercial center
column3: urban park
column4: and health and education infrastructure. The original plan also called for a business and administrative center
column5: built in the mid-1990s
column6: when the city population grew rapidly more than doubling in ten years.Three industrial zones were placed adjacent to the port in the northern part of the city
column7: taking into account the prevailing southern winds which take air pollution away from the city. The plan had its problems
column8: however
column9: including asymmetric growth of upscale and poorer neighborhoods and the long-time lack of a main business and administrative center.The city was planned for a maximum of 250
column11: and an additional area in the south was reserved for further development.In 2012
column12: a plan to build an industrial zone on part of the Ashdod Sand Dune was approved. The plan calls for a hi-tech industrial park
column14: and coffee shops to be built adjacent to the train station. It will cover 400 dunams (0.4 km2; 0.2 sq mi)
column16: with the rest of the area being preserved as a nature reserve. In addition
column17: the Port of Ashdod is undergoing a massive expansion program.

column1: The Ashdod-Nitzanim sand dune nature reserve is a 20-kilometer (12-mile) stretch of sand dunes on the southern outskirts of Ashdod.
Ashdod has a Mediterranean climate with hot summers
column2: pleasant spring and fall
column3: and cool
column4: rainy winters. As a seaside town
column5: the humidity tends to be high many times year round
column6: and rain occurs mainly from November to March. In winter
column7: temperatures seldom drop below 5 °C (41 °F) and are more likely to be in the range of 10–15 °C (50–59 °F)
column8: while in summer the average is 27 °C (81 °F). The average annual rainfall is 510 mm (20 in).

column1: Ashdod is one of the most important industrial centers in Israel. All industrial activities in the city are located in northern areas such as the port area
column2: the northern industrial zone
column3: and around the Lachish River. The port of Ashdod is the largest port in Israel
column4: handling about 60% of Israel's port cargo. It was mainly upgraded in recent years and will be able to provide berths for Panamax ships. Various shipping companies offices are also located in the port area which also is home to an Eshkol A power station and coal terminal.

column1: The Northern industrial zone is located on Highway 41 and includes various industry including an oil refinery
column2: which is one of only two in the country. The heavy industry zone located south of the Lachish River was once the main industrial center in Ashdod. Recently
column3: however
column4: leisure facilities have moved into the area. There is still some industry here
column5: however
column6: such as a Teva Pharmaceutical Industries plant
column7: construction components producer Ashtrom
column8: and Solbar a soybean oil producer. Ashdod is also home to Elta
column9: a part of Israel Aircraft Industries where radar equipment

column2: however
column3: when the mall shopping culture developed in Israel

column9: billed at the time as the city's largest shopping mall

column12: following the examples of the Tel Aviv Central Bus Station and the Jerusalem Central Bus Station. The Sea Mall
column13: a three-story mall near the government offices

column2: Ashdod's only general hospital
column3: serves the city and the surrounding area. It is a 300-bed hospital
column4: and its "bomb shelter" design with thick concrete walls offers sufficient protection so as to keep operating without having to transfer patients during a time of war. It is also a university hospital affiliated with Ben-Gurion University of the Negev. The hospital opened in 2017. Prior to the opening of the hospital
column5: Ashdod did not have a general hospital
column6: and residents in need of hospitalization had to travel to Kaplan Medical Center in Rehovot or Barzilai Medical Center in Ashkelon.

column1: There are public and private clinics operating in the city. A special clinic run by Hatzalah operates at times when all other clinics in the city are closed.
Ashdod is located on the historic Via Maris. Highway 4 was developed following this route along the southern sea shore of Israel; it serves as the main connection to the north
column2: towards the Tel Aviv metropolitan area
column3: and to the south
column4: towards Ashkelon. Ad Halom junction was planned as the main entrance to the city from the east.Ashdod Interchange was opened in 2009.

column1: The interchange continues the freeway section of Highway 4 further south
column2: by removing the traffic light at this junction
column3: and also added grade separation with the railway. The other main road in the area is Highway 41 which served the city from the start of its modern history. This road runs from west to east towards Gedera and it is the main transport link to the port of Ashdod and the industrial zones
column4: and connects to Highway 4 with an interchange.

column2: Ashdod won a NIS 220 million grant from the Israeli Transport Ministry to improve public transportation and decrease private car use. According to the municipality's plans
column3: a 20-kilometer ring of road arteries will be given priority in public transportation. These arteries will carry four bus rapid transit lines. In the city's more crowded areas
column4: such as Herzl Boulevard or the western part of Menachem Begin Boulevard
column5: a public transportation lane will be paved in the center of the road. In other areas
column6: the right-hand lane will be reserved for public transportation. Buses will also be given priority at traffic lights; electronic devices will allow a bus to signal its approach
column7: causing the light to turn green. In addition
column8: an electric-powered bicycle rental network will be set up
column9: and 22 kilometres (14 miles) of bicycle paths will be paved in the city.

column1: The passenger railway connection to Ashdod opened in 1992 after the renovation of the historical railway to Egypt. Ashdod railway station is on Israel Railways' Binyamina/Netanya – Tel Aviv – Ashkelon line and it is located near Ad Halom Junction. The station was upgraded in 2003 when a new terminal building was built. The station building is modern
column2: but proper road access to it was only organized on September 23
column4: when a new road to the station was opened.There is also heavy freight traffic in the area. Port of Ashdod has its own railway spur line as well as a special terminal for potash brought from the Sodom area and exported abroad.

column1: A new central bus station opened in 1996. It serves as the terminus both for inter- and intracity lines. The central bus station is attached to the City Mall. Intercity bus lines connect the city with most population centers in central and southern Israel. Following is the list of bus companies serving routes at the central bus station:
The Egged Ta'avura company has been operating urban buses in Ashdod since 2007. In addition
column2: a share taxi service exists in Ashdod
column3: operated by Moniyot HaIr. Most share taxi lines coincide with intracity bus lines.

column1: There is a passenger pier in the Port of Ashdod. The traffic at this gateway is constantly growing
column2: especially due to cruise ship activities. The other sea gateway is Blue Marina.

column1: Ashdod has seen much of its growth as the result of absorption of immigrants. The first settlers were Jewish immigrants from Morocco and Egypt. In the 1960s Ashdod accepted a large number of immigrants from Romania
column2: followed by a large number from Georgia (then part of the Soviet Union) in the 1970s. More than 60
column3: 000 Russian Jews from the former Soviet Union who immigrated to Israel in the 1990s following the collapse of the Soviet Union settled in Ashdod. Recent demographic figures suggest that about 32% of the city's population are new immigrants
column4: 85% of whom are originally from the former Soviet Union. During the 1990s the city absorbed a large number of Beta Israel immigrants from Ethiopia
column5: and in more recent years Ashdod absorbed a large number of immigrants from the United States
column6: United Kingdom
column7: France
column8: Argentina
column9: and South Africa. Many of the 60
column11: India who moved to Israel also settled there. Ashdod also receives a significant amount of internal migration
column12: especially from the Gush Dan region.

column1: Over 95% of Ashdod's population is Jewish
column2: over 30% of whom are religiously observant. Despite this
column3: the city is generally secular
column4: although most of the non-Jewish population is a result of mixed marriages. About 100 families are affiliated with the Pittsburg Hasidic group
column5: established here in 1969 by Grand Rabbi Avraham Abba Leifer and continued today by his son
column6: Grand Rabbi Mordechai Yissachar Ber Leifer. Ashdod has many synagogues serving different streams of Judaism. The city is also home to the world's largest Karaite community
column7: about five thousand strong. There is also a Scandinavian Seamen Protestant church
column8: established by Norwegian Righteous Among the Nations pastor Per Faye-Hansen.

column1: Ashdod was declared a city in 1968. The Ashdod City Council has twenty-five elected members
column2: one of whom is the mayor. The mayor serves a five-year term and appoints six deputies. The current mayor of Ashdod
column3: Yehiel Lasri
column4: was last elected in 2008 after Zvi Zilker

column1: has been in office continuously since 1989. Within the city council there are various factions representing different population groups. The headquarters of the Ashdod Municipality and the mayor's office are at city hall. This new municipal building is located in the main culture and business area.
Ashdod is home to the Israeli Andalusian Orchestra
column2: which performs Andalusian classical music. It is an Arabic music style that originates from Moorish Iberia or Al-Andalus
column3: has been jealously preserved in its original form by Arab and Jewish musicians of the Maghreb over the centuries
column4: and has left its mark on the cante flamenco
column5: the flamenco singing style
column6: perhaps better known in the West. The orchestra was awarded the Israel Prize in 2006.Ashdod also has one of the biggest open theaters in Israel - Amphi Ashdod that can hosts more than 6
column7: 400 guests. The Amphi hosts Ashdod's international art festival "Méditerranée".

column1: The MonArt Centre for the Arts

column3: a music center and the Ashdod Museum of Art
column4: is a performing arts center which comprises different galleries
column5: art schools
column6: studios and events. The ambitious architectural complex has been inaugurated in 2003. Theatre and concerts are hosted in several cultural venues; the most important are performed at the Ashdod Performing Arts Center
column7: a new 938-seat concert hall of distinct elegance and originality designed by Israeli architect Haim Dotan and inaugurated in 2012 in the city's cultural center. Ashdod plays host to many national and international music festivals

column10: and serves as a home for 600 young musicians in different fields.

column1: The Corinne Mamane Museum of Philistine Culture  is worldwide the only museum dedicated to this topic. It reopened in 2014 with a new interactive exhibition.  The Museum displays significant Philistine artifacts form each of the five cities in the Philistine pentapolis.

column2: located in the MonArt center (see above at "Music and performing arts")
column3: has 12 galleries and two exhibition halls. In an architectural echo of the Louvre
column4: the entrance to the museum is through a glass pyramid. In 2003 the internal spaces of the museum were redesigned by the architects Eyal Weizman
column5: Rafi Segal and Manuel Herz.

column2: F.C. Ironi Ashdod represents the city in the Israeli Premier League. The club is known for its successful football school. It is also home to Hapoel Ashdod F.C.

column1: Ashdod plays host to many national and international sporting tournaments

column4: like as windsurfing and Scuba diving. The Ashdod Marina offers yachting services.
